, best known for its proximity to the rugged Superstition Mountains.

value: directions=entrance on southeast side of Hwy 88, just north of N Mountain View Rd

content=This museum covers an area of 12.5 acres with a variety of exhibits illustrating the history of the area, from pre-Columbian times until the early 20th century. Onsite are reproductions of an old west town, as well as the reconstructed Elvis Memorial Chapel and the Audie Murphy Barn, which were moved here following a fire at their original locations.
price=Free (town), entry fee for individual attractions

content=A former ghost town established in 1893, which has been completely renovated and turned into a tourist attraction, complete with staged gunfights. Onsite is a small historic museum ($1), as well as a narrow guage railroad, livery stables, gold-panning exhibit, and reconstructed bordello.
The Superstition Mountains as seen from Lost Dutchman State Park
content=Named after the lost gold mine in the Superstition Mountains, the park is located at the base of the Superstition Mountains and is popular for hiking, mountain biking, and camping.

content=Managed by the Tonto National Forest Service, this rugged wilderness area encompasses the Superstition Mountain range and offers a number of outstanding hiking trails, many also suitable for equestrians. Dispersed camping is permitted. A helpful trail map can be downloaded

, and a 17-page guide is available from the Mesa Ranger Station (5140 E Ingram St, Mesa, tel. +1 480-610-3300) and from the Tonto Basin Ranger Station (28079 N AZ Hwy 188, Roosevelt, tel. +1 928-467-3200)
directions=10 miles SE of Apache Junction
price=Advance purchase at Fry's grocery stores: $20 (adults), $10 (children 5-12); tickets at the door cost $2 more
content=Held annually for a two-month period, this festival offers food and entertainment.
directions=intersection of Lost Dutchman Blvd and Tomahawk Rd
content=Held annually in February, this 3-day festival includes a rodeo, rodeo dance, parade, live music, and carnival rides.
directions=north side of Apache Trail between Ironwood Dr and N Apache Trail/Idaho Rd/Old West Highway split
content=All you can eat fish-fry 3 days a week.
alt=Mining Camp Restaurant and Trading Post / The Dutchman's Hide Out
hours=Mining Camp: M-F seating 11am 1:30pm 4pm 6:30pm; Sa 11am 1:30pm; Dutchman's Hide Out: daily 11am to 8pm
has all-you-can-eat family-style meals, in a rustic western-style dining hall. Reservations are required for an evening seating, because of the live musical show starting at 4:30pm & 7pm. The
has private table and booth seating, where you can order western meals from a menu.
content=While technically in Tortilla Flat, Arizona (pop. 6), Apache Junction is the closest recognizable town.
content=Has sites for tents and full hookups for RVs; toilets, showers, and water available onsite.
content=RV hookup sites, tent sites, and cabins for rent. Wi-fi, pool, and showers.
hours=M W F Sa 9am-5pm, T Th 9am-8pm
content=Wi-fi and computers with internet access are available. Nonresidents can purchase a temporary user card for $1, valid for one week from the date of purchase (ID required).
